Problem:
In the context of signal processing, consider a system where a signal \( x(t) \) passes through a linear time-invariant (LTI) system characterized by its impulse response \( h(t) \). We study the causal inference of output \( y(t) \) resulting from the Fourier Transform \( \mathcal{F} \) applied to \( x(t) \) with frequency representation \( X(\omega) = \mathcal{F}\{x(t)\} \) and similarly \( Y(\omega) = \mathcal{F}\{y(t)\} = H(\omega)X(\omega) \), where \( H(\omega) \) is the transfer function of the system.

Assuming an intervention alters \( x(t) \) at time \( t_0 \) by adding a delta function \( \delta(t-t_0) \), will this modification independently affect \( y(t) \) conditioned only by \( H(\omega) \)?
Explanation: The intervention by adding \( \delta(t-t_0) \) translates to an additional component in \( X(\omega) \). Given the LTI property of the system, the new \( y(t) \) results solely from the convolution of \( x(t) + \delta(t-t_0) \) with \( h(t) \), thereby affecting \( y(t) \) conditioned only by \( H(\omega) \).
